CompuBench is the first professional OpenCL benchmark to test and compare the parallel compute performance of CPUs, GPUs and accelerators of desktop devices. CompuBench CL is developed by Kishonti Ltd. If you are interested in what we do, please visit our website at kishonti.net!
CompuBench CL is a cross-platform 3D graphics benchmark to measure the performance of your device and compare it to other devices.
CompuBench GL is a cross-platform 3D graphics benchmark to measure the performance of your device and compare it to other devices.
CompuBench CUDA is a cross-platform 3D graphics benchmark to measure the performance of your device and compare it to other devices.
CompuBench Metal is a cross-platform 3D graphics benchmark to measure the performance of your device and compare it to other devices.
Failed to load OpenCL.dll.\nPlease reinstall graphics driver or the OpenCL SDK.
Intel CPUs with AMD APP SDK are not supported
Hight Quality Computer Generated Imagery and Rendering

Face detector based on the Viola-Jones algorithm. Face detection is extensively used in biometrics and digital image processing to determine locations and sizes of human faces in digital images. Result metrics: mpixel/sec

Test based on dense motion vector calculation using variational method. Optical flow is widely used for video compression and enhancing video quality in computer vision-based use cases such as driver assistance systems or motion detection. Result metrics: mpixel/sec

Test of the FFT algorithm based on ocean wave simulation. The fast Fourier transform computes transformations of time or space to frequency and vice versa. FFTs are widely used in engineering, science, and mathematics. Result metrics: frames/sec
Particle Simulation in a spatial grid using the discrete element method. The result of the simulation is visualized as shaded point sprite spheres with OpenGL. Result metrics: minteractions/sec
Path tracer featuring dynamically updated acceleration structure and global illumination. Result metrics: frames/sec
This test replicates a typical video composition pipeline with effects such as pixelate, mask, mix and blur. Result metrics: frames/sec
The popular Bitcoin algorithm tests the integer performance of the device. Result metrics: mhash/sec

GFXBench is a 3D graphics benchmark to test the graphics performance of your device and compare the results to other devices across all popular platforms. GFXBench is developed by Kishonti Ltd. If you are interested in what we do, please visit our website at kishonti.net!
GFXBench is a cross-platform 3D graphics benchmark to measure the performance of your device and compare it to other devices.
This test will display a mosaic render of the %s scene while computing high resolution frames offscreen.

GFXBench is a 3D graphics benchmark to test the graphics performance of your device and compare the results to other devices across all popular platforms. GFXBench is developed by Kishonti Ltd. If you are interested in what we do, please visit our website at kishonti.net!
GFXBench is a cross-platform 3D graphics benchmark to measure the performance of your device and compare it to other devices.
Device is working correctly. View OpenGL details on InfoPage.

High-end game-like scenes to test your devices overall 3D graphics performance. The test engines feature complex effects to stress the GPU and give feedback on its 3D graphics performance delivered when gaming or performing other GPU-intensive tasks (e.g. UI rendering, navigation).

Measures the pure shader compute performance of your device by using a complex fragment shader and rendering a single full-screen quad. To see how your device performs at its native resolution, run the Onscreen test. To compare your scores to other devices, use the Offscreen version that runs at 1080p on all devices. Required minimum API: ES 2.0 / GL 3.0

Measures the pure shader compute performance of your device by using a complex fragment shader and rendering a single full-screen quad. To see how your device performs at its native resolution, run the Onscreen test. To compare your scores to other devices, use the Offscreen version that runs at 1080p on all devices. Required minimum API: ES 2.0 / GL 3.0

This is an enhanced version of the original ALU test found in GFXBench 3.0. It approximates the fragment shader computing load of the Manhattan test better, by rendering 64 point lights in multiple passes over a captured Manhattan frame. Emissive and ambient terms are also evaluated along with the diffuse lighting. Required minimum API: OpenGL ES 3.0 / OpenGL 4.1

This is an enhanced version of the original ALU Offscreen test found in GFXBench 3.0. It approximates the fragment shader computing load of the Manhattan test better, by rendering 64 point lights in multiple passes over a captured Manhattan frame. Emissive and ambient terms are also evaluated along with the diffuse lighting. Required minimum API: OpenGL ES 3.0 / OpenGL 4.1

Measures the device's alpha blending performance by rendering semi-transparent screen-aligned quads with high-resolution uncompressed textures. To see how your device performs at its native resolution, run the Onscreen test. To compare your scores to other devices, use the Offscreen version that runs at 1080p on all devices. Required minimum API: ES 2.0 / GL 3.0

Measures the device's alpha blending performance by rendering semi-transparent screen-aligned quads with high-resolution uncompressed textures. To see how your device performs at its native resolution, run the Onscreen test. To compare your scores to other devices, use the Offscreen version that runs at 1080p on all devices. Required minimum API: ES 2.0 / GL 3.0
Checks if your device works correctly with shader compile and rendering.

Measures the OpenGL drivers CPU overhead by rendering a large number of simple objects one-by-one, changing device state for each item. The frequency of the state changes reflects real-world applications. To see how your device performs at its native resolution, run the Onscreen test. To compare your scores to other devices, use the Offscreen version that runs at 1080p on all devices. Required minimum API: ES 2.0 / GL 3.0

Measures the OpenGL drivers CPU overhead by rendering a large number of simple objects one-by-one, changing device state for each item. The frequency of the state changes reflects real-world applications. To see how your device performs at its native resolution, run the Onscreen test. To compare your scores to other devices, use the Offscreen version that runs at 1080p on all devices. Required minimum API: ES 2.0 / GL 3.0

This is an enhanced version of the original Driver Overhead test found in GFXBench 3.0, and approximates the graphics driver's CPU load when running the Manhattan high-level test. It renders the same amount of geometry twice to add a glow effect, using lots of draw calls, changing rendertargets, vertex formats and shaders as well. The test also alters graphics states like depth-test and blending between blocks of draw calls. Required minimum API: OpenGL ES 3.0 / OpenGL 4.1

This is an enhanced version of the original Driver Overhead Offscreen test found in GFXBench 3.0, and approximates the graphics driver's CPU load when running the Manhattan high-level test. It renders the same amount of geometry twice to add a glow effect, using lots of draw calls, changing rendertargets, vertex formats and shaders as well. The test also alters graphics states like depth-test and blending between blocks of draw calls. Required minimum API: OpenGL ES 3.0 / OpenGL 4.1

Measures the devices texturing performance by rendering four layers of compressed textures. This is a common scenario in gaming. To see how your device performs at its native resolution, run the Onscreen test. To compare your score to other devices, use the Offscreen version that runs at 1080p on all devices. Required minimum API: ES 2.0 / GL 3.0

Measures the devices texturing performance by rendering four layers of compressed textures. This is a common scenario in gaming. To see how your device performs at its native resolution, run the Onscreen test. To compare your score to other devices, use the Offscreen version that runs at 1080p on all devices. Required minimum API: ES 2.0 / GL 3.0

This is an enhanced version of the original Fill test found in GFXBench 3.0. It approximates the texturing load of the Manhattan high-level test better, by rendering multiple layers of textured planes over each other. The amount of textures and their formats matches those of Manhattan, including uncompressed screen-sized sources, depth-format buffers, and cube-maps. Required minimum API: OpenGL ES 3.0 / OpenGL 4.1. Score: transferred texels, in MTexels/sec

This is an enhanced version of the original Fill Offscreen test found in GFXBench 3.0. It approximates the texturing load of the Manhattan high-level test better, by rendering multiple layers of textured planes over each other. The amount of textures and their formats matches those of Manhattan, including uncompressed screen-sized sources, depth-format buffers, and cube-maps. Required minimum API: OpenGL ES 3.0 / OpenGL 4.1. Score: transferred texels, in MTexels/sec

This is the original Manhattan test, first introduced in GFXBench 3.0, which uses the ES 3.0 / GL 4.1 capabilities of your device. The test scene is a night-time city environment with lots of lights to illuminate the scenery. It uses deferred rendering and multi-render target (MRT) for the geometry pass (four color attachments as textures), diffuse and specular lighting and features complex effects such as depth shadow map, cloaking effect, post-process effects (bloom, depth of field), occlusion query and animated volumetric light shafts. To see how your device performs at its native resolution, run the Onscreen test. To compare your scores to other devices, use the Offscreen version that runs at 1080p on all devices. Required minimum API: ES 3.0 / GL 4.1

To see how your device performs at its native resolution, run the Onscreen test. To compare your scores to other devices, use the Offscreen version that runs at 1080p on all devices. This is an enhanced version of the original Manhattan test found in GFXBench 3.0, showcasing advanced visual effects achieved with OpenGL ES 3.1 / OpenGL 4.3. Compute shaders and indirect draw calls are used for the lightning effect, for the HDR with luminance adaptation, and the bloom thresholding as well. The depth-of-field effect is also enhanced. Required minimum API: OpenGL ES 3.1 / OpenGL 4.3

This combined test measures your devices battery life and FPS stability in a gaming scene by running the same high-level test for 30 times. It logs FPS and the battery charge during the test and the results are displayed in a battery graph. The test produces two scores, one is the estimated battery life in minutes while the other is the number of frames rendered by the slowest test run. Required minimum API: OpenGL ES 3.1 / OpenGL 4.3

This is the original T-Rex test, first introduced in GFXBench 2.7. Based on ES 2.0 / GL 3.0, the T-Rex test includes highly detailed textures, materials, complex geometry, particles with animated textures and a post-process effect: motion blur. The graphics pipeline also features effects, e.g.: planar reflection, specular highlights and soft-shadows. To see how your device performs at its native resolution, run the Onscreen test. To compare your scores to other devices, use the Offscreen version that runs at 1080p on all devices. Required minimum API: ES 2.0 / GL 3.0

This is the original T-Rex Offscreen test, first introduced in GFXBench 2.7. Based on ES 2.0 / GL 3.0, the T-Rex test includes highly detailed textures, materials, complex geometry, particles with animated textures and a post-process effect: motion blur. The graphics pipeline also features effects, e.g.: planar reflection, specular highlights and soft-shadows. To see how your device performs at its native resolution, run the Onscreen test. To compare your scores to other devices, use the Offscreen version that runs at 1080p on all devices. Required minimum API: ES 2.0 / GL 3.0

This is the original Battery Test, first introduced in GFXBench 3.0. This combined test measures your devices battery life and FPS stability in a gaming scene by running the same high-level test for 30 times. It logs FPS and the battery charge during the test and the results are displayed in a battery graph. The test produces two scores, one is the estimated battery life in minutes while the other is the number of frames rendered by the slowest test run. Required minimum API: ES 2.0 / GL 3.0

This is the original Render Quality test, first introduced in GFXBench 3.0. It measures the visual fidelity of your device in a high-end gaming scene. The score is the peak signal-to-noise ratio (PSNR) based on mean square error (MSE) compared to a pre-rendered reference image. Required minimum API: ES 2.0 / GL 3.0

This is the original Render Quality (high precision) test, first introduced in GFXBench 3.0. It measures the visual fidelity of your device in a high-end gaming scene. The score is the peak signal-to-noise ratio (PSNR) based on mean square error (MSE) compared to a pre-rendered reference image. Required minimum API: ES 2.0 / GL 3.0

Car Chase is our game-like test that fully exploits the capabilities of the Android Extension Pack. It uses deferred shading combined by image-based lighting to render the scene in a full HDR environment. The test uses geometry shaders and tessellation, dynamic reflections, physically-based shading, compute based particles and occlusion culling, dynamic cascaded shadows and advanced post-process effects, like motion blur, screen-space ambient occlusion, depth of field and lens flare. To see how your device performs at its native resolution, run the Onscreen test. To compare your scores to other devices, use the Offscreen version that runs at 1080p on all devices. Required minimum API: ES 3.1 with AEP / GL 4.3

Aztec Ruins is our cross API game-like test available for most modern graphics APIs. It features real-time global illumination over deferred rendering combined with physically-based shading. It uses a variety of popular rendering algorithms such as occlusion culling, dynamic cascaded shadows and advanced post-process effects, like motion blur, screen-space ambient occlusion, depth of field. The High Tier version features particle simulation and higher quality illumination and effects over Normal Tier. To see how your device performs at its native resolution, run the Onscreen test. To compare your scores to other devices, use the Offscreen version that runs at 4K or 1440p on all devices.

Car Chase is our game-like test that fully exploits the capabilities of the iOS 10 and macOS Sierra. It uses deferred shading combined by image-based lighting to render the scene in a full HDR environment. The test uses tessellation, dynamic reflections, physically-based shading, compute based particles and occlusion culling (macOS only), dynamic cascaded shadows and advanced post-process effects, like motion blur, screen-space ambient occlusion, depth of field and lens flare. To see how your device performs at its native resolution, run the Onscreen test. To compare your scores to other devices, use the Offscreen version that runs at 1080p on all devices.

Measures the pure shader compute performance of your device by using a complex fragment shader and rendering a single full-screen quad. To see how your device performs at its native resolution, run the Onscreen test. To compare your scores to other devices, use the Offscreen version that runs at 1080p on all devices. Required minimum API: DirectX 9.1

Measures the pure shader compute performance of your device by using a complex fragment shader and rendering a single full-screen quad. To see how your device performs at its native resolution, run the Onscreen test. To compare your scores to other devices, use the Offscreen version that runs at 1080p on all devices. Required minimum API: DirectX 9.1

Measures the device's alpha blending performance by rendering semi-transparent screen-aligned quads with high-resolution uncompressed textures. To see how your device performs at its native resolution, run the Onscreen test. To compare your scores to other devices, use the Offscreen version that runs at 1080p on all devices. Required minimum API: DirectX 9.1

Required minimum API: DirectX 9.1
Checks if your device works correctly with shader compile and rendering.

Measures the DirectX drivers CPU overhead by rendering a large number of simple objects one-by-one, changing device state for each item. The frequency of the state changes reflects real-world applications. To see how your device performs at its native resolution, run the Onscreen test. To compare your scores to other devices, use the Offscreen version that runs at 1080p on all devices. Required minimum API: DirectX 9.1

Measures the devices texturing performance by rendering four layers of compressed textures. This is a common scenario in gaming. Our very first test to utilize the DirectX 10.0 capabilities of your device. The test scene is a night-time city environment with lots of lights to illuminate the scenery. It uses deferred rendering and multi-render target (MRT) for the geometry pass (four color attachments as textures), diffuse and specular lighting and features complex effects such as depth shadow map, cloaking effect, post-process effects (bloom, depth of field), occlusion query and animated volumetric light shafts. To see how your device performs at its native resolution, run the Onscreen test. To compare your scores to other devices, use the Offscreen version that runs at 1080p on all devices. Required minimum API: DirectX 10.0

It uses deferred rendering and multi-render target (MRT) for the geometry pass (four color attachments as textures), diffuse and specular lighting and features complex effects such as depth shadow map, cloaking effect, post-process effects (bloom, depth of field), occlusion query and animated volumetric light shafts. To see how your device performs at its native resolution, run the Onscreen test. To compare your scores to other devices, use the Offscreen version that runs at 1080p on all devices. Required minimum API: DirectX 10.0
Modified Manhattan scene using compute shaders in ES 3.1 of the following effects: DoF, robot lightning effect, tile-based lighting.

Based on DirectX 9.1, the T-Rex test includes highly detailed textures, materials, complex geometry, particles with animated textures and a post-process effect: motion blur. The graphics pipeline also features effects, e.g.: planar reflection, specular highlights and soft-shadows. To see how your device performs at its native resolution, run the Onscreen test. To compare your scores to other devices, use the Offscreen version that runs at 1080p on all devices. Required minimum API: DirectX 9.1

Based on DirectX 9.1, the T-Rex test includes highly detailed textures, materials, complex geometry, particles with animated textures and a post-process effect: motion blur. The graphics pipeline also features effects, e.g.: planar reflection, specular highlights and soft-shadows. To see how your device performs at its native resolution, run the Onscreen test. To compare your scores to other devices, use the Offscreen version that runs at 1080p on all devices. Required minimum API: DirectX 9.1

This combined test measures your devices battery life and FPS stability in a gaming scene by running the same high-level test for 30 times. It logs FPS and the battery charge during the test and the results are displayed in a battery graph. The test produces two scores, one is the estimated battery life in minutes while the other is the number of frames rendered by the slowest test run. Required minimum API: DirectX 9.1

Measures the visual fidelity of your device in a high-end gaming scene. The score is the peak signal-to-noise ratio (PSNR) based on mean square error (MSE) compared to a pre-rendered reference image. Required minimum API: DirectX 9.1

Please note that the app requires active internet connection. The application data is downloaded and synchronized at every startup and the results are uploaded to the server. The collected hardware and result data enable us to provide a comprehensive database for comparing devices. Please also note the following:
Outgoing data:
- Crash report: the application log file will be sent to us at the next application startup in case of a crash. Otherwise it will be deleted. - The application gathers information on the most important hardware data of your device and uploads it to our website database. - The application also uploads every test result to our website database.
Incoming data:
- The application will download test and language files, pictures and a copy of the database.
If you do not allow sending us information or test results you will only be able to run a basic test. You can still browse the result database and check your hardware specifications. Thank you for your understanding.
Do you allow the outgoing traffic?
